title: Labour fury as Stephen Barclay urges MPs to 'come together' like late Mo Mowlam
text:

Stephen Barclay enrages Labour by mentioning late Mo Mowlam, a key Labour figure in securing the Good Friday Agreement, as he urges MPs to "come together and move on".

Cries of "shame" were heard from the Opposition benches after the Brexit Secretary referred to Ms Mowlam's achievements and made a joke from the title of her book Momentum, noting: "In the days before it was a faction forcing out its own colleagues."

Ms Mowlam, who was instrumental in the Good Friday Agreement, was known for her no nonsense approach and willingness to talk to all sides.

The former MP, who passed away from a brain tumour, is revered as a hero in Labour circles.

(Image: PA)

The biggest change from Theresa May's deal to the fresh agreement secured in Brussels this week are in Northern Ireland.

Boris Johnson has succeeded in scrapping Theresa May's backstop - but conceded to a regulatory border in the Irish sea.



Northern Ireland (NI) will stay in the UK customs territory, meaning after a new trade deal, goods can be imported just as they are onto the British mainland.

(Image: Birmingham Post and Mail)

But EU customs rules will apply to goods entering NI that are deemed "at-risk" of moving into the EU.

In a meaningful climbdown, the UK government agreed that Northern Ireland will remain aligned to EU single market rules - notably on agricultural policy and VAT - to avoid checks on goods crossing the Irish border.

And there will be"checks and controls" on the relevant goods when they pass between the NI and mainland Britain.

The arrangements will come into effect at the start of 2021 and, after an initial four-year period, Stormont Assembly members will vote whether to continue to apply them.

Significantly, that vote will be conducted on a simple majority headcount and will not require the support of a majority of unionists and a majority of nationalists under the contentious "petition of concern" mechanism.

This means the DUP will not have the chance to exercise a veto.

(Image: UK PARLIAMENTARY RECORDING UNIT HANDOUT/EPA-EFE/REX)

That four-year extension can be extended to eight if both nationalists and unionists back the setup.

The previously agreed settlement on citizens' rights after Brexit and Britain's divorce bill stay as they were.

That also goes for a transition period of 14 months until the end of 2020, which can be extended by one year or two years.

But on the key area of workers' rights, the deal was described as "a leap backwards" by Unison - after it failed to match Mr May's "regression lock" promise that rights in the UK would not fall all behind those in the EU.

DUP Westminster leader Nigel Dodds today asked whether the Government's support for a majority vote at Stormont on Northern Ireland's consent to its customs arrangements in the future meant the end of vetoes in the Assembly.

He added: "Can we now take it that the policy of the Government is to do away with vetoes, for instance, about getting the Assembly up and running? Four out of the five parties in Northern Ireland want it up and running?"

Responding, Mr Barclay said: "This is about a reserved matter that applies to our international agreements as a United Kingdom and not the powers that sit with the Assembly within the Good Friday agreement.

"And that is why there wasn't a willingness to give one community a power of veto over the other."
description: There were cries of "shame" from the Labour benches at a joke about the late MP's autobiography
